items.name: Phase 6
items.subTitle: Review and revision

content.value: Diagnostic service provision is a rapidly changing field and this impacts the composition of the
. Changes may include:

Technological changes: technologies are constantly being updated and revised, new technologies and assay formats emerge, and old diagnostic tests may become obsolete because they are being replaced by better options, cheaper and/or more user-friendly technologies.
Disease changes: priority diseases may change due to changing epidemiological patterns and the emergence of new pathogens.
Clinical care changes: new treatment and monitoring options may become available that require changes in the diagnostic services.
System changes: changes in system elements may allow for the inclusion of more priority diseases and/or diagnostic tests in the

. This may include changes leading to strengthening of the health care and/or laboratory facilities providing opportunities for cascading tests to lower tiers, but also the expansion of the sample referral system, changes in the funding landscape, etc.
In addition, the
is regularly revised, and updated versions are being published.
Phase 6 describes the process that countries must follow for regularly reviewing and updating the current
. We suggest doing this at least once every three years.
Phase 6 starts with updating or repeating the assessments done in
and
to ensure that decisions are based on the latest information (Steps
and
Based on the up-to-date assessment findings and Monitoring and Evaluation (&&M&E) data (
), the
will consult with relevant expert groups to give their input on financial aspects (Step
), and health system aspects (Step
) that may influence the revision of the
The imaging expert group (Step
) and the laboratory expert group (Step
) provide input on technological, disease and clinical care changes that that may influence the revision of the
. These activities can be performed in parallel.
Finally, these findings are discussed and consolidated during one or more sessions of the
, resulting in a list of candidate diagnostic tests and required changes to the
that need to go through the steps described in Phase 3 starting with Step
, making the development and updating of the
a cyclical process ensuring that the diagnostic services are continuously improving.

items.name: Phase 5
items.subTitle: Implement the NEDL to optimize diagnostic services

content.value: For each diagnostic test the

provides the current tier at which it can currently be implemented and the desired tier(s) at which it should ideally be implemented to ensure optimal diagnostic services to the entire population throughout the country. In addition, there is a list of target diagnostic tests. To implement the
, an implementation plan is developed in this phase. This can be done by the
(as we have assumed here) or the National Laboratory Working Group (
), Technical Working Group (
), National Laboratory Coordination Team (
) or whatever the name is in the country, or the country can decide to establish a separate
implementation committee. The approach is described below and visualized in Figure 1.
The process of implementing the
starts with listing all diagnostic facilities in the country (
), and developing a list of actions required for:
Implementing current diagnostic tests at current tiers (output of
) (current diagnostic tests may not yet be implemented at all facilities at current tiers)
Implementing current diagnostic tests at desired tiers (output of
Implementing target diagnostic tests (output of
These activities include analysis of the requirements at health system as well as individual facility level.
These lists serve as basis for:
Developing a Specific, Measurable, Agreed, Realistic and Time-bound (
) and costed â€œ
implementation plan
â€ with a duration of one year, described in

Providing input for the amendment of the National Health and Laboratory Policies and Strategic Plans: during Activities 5.2a-c, a number of challenges to, or gaps in, the diagnostic services system will have been identified that are essential for the implementation and expansion of the
. Most of these challenges can be overcome with the â€œ
implementation plan

â€. However, some challenges will require more extensive changes, for example in legislation or procedures. These challenges and possible solutions must be discussed on a regular basis with the experts involved in the development and updating of the National Health/Laboratory Policies, Strategic- and Operational Plans. This is described in

content.value: Use the

to list the contact details of all diagnostic facilities in the country. This also includes facilities without laboratories.

If resources permit, the country may also decide to map the diagnostic facilities. This will, for example, provide insight in the density and location of diagnostic facilities at the various tiers, hence accessibility of specific diagnostic services, in the various parts of the country. Alternatively, the country may decide to make
implementation part of a full-fledged Diagnostic Network Optimization (
) exercise.

aims to understand how diagnostic services are organized in a country to inform the optimal location of tools, testing capacity and sample referral systems. It uses national data to understand existing gaps that limit access to and utilization of diagnostic services, and to design the best solutions to address these gaps. Implementation of an
fits excellently in a
exercise. More information on
can be found here:
Diagnostic network optimization - FIND (finddx.org)

items.name: Activity 5.3B
items.subTitle: Provide input for the amendment of the National Health and Laboratory Policies and/or Strategic Plans

content.value: To inform the improvement of national policies and/or strategic plans to ensure reinforcement of diagnostic services to achieve the
-target situation

Most countries have a National Health Policy as well as a National Laboratory Policy and/or Strategic Plan. The development, review and updating of these policies and plans, both for laboratory services as well as imaging services, are led by the Ministry of Health, who often delegates these tasks to a group of experts. For the laboratory services this group has different names in different countries. The most widely used names are
or
. We will use the term
here.
During the development and implementation of the
points for improvement/reinforcement of the diagnostic system have been identified in
, and
. Some of these points for improvement can be immediately included in the implementation plans, others require more extensive or profound changes to the current diagnostic services.
The
and

are two separate entities, even though there may be overlap in their memberships. The development/amendment of the National Health/Laboratory Policies and Strategic Plans are the responsibility of the
and the
. The
should avoid setting up parallel systems where the
develops a parallel strategic plan for reinforcement of the diagnostic services to implement and expand the

. Rather, points that require extensive changes to the system should be directly included in the National Health/Laboratory Policies and Strategic Plans. This requires regular communication between the
and the entities responsible for these policies and plans. The same applies for the amendment of guidelines, legal documents, etc. which may also be affected.

Policies and strategic plans often cover a time span of 5-10 years, which would mean that the required profound changes would have to wait a long time. However, the required changes may be included in the yearly operational plans as laboratory/health system improvement activities.

There are two different types of stakeholders (a more exhaustive list of stakeholders is provided in
Stakeholders that have a vested interest in preparing or changing (parts of) the
, for example, civil society groups that want to add their focus disease to the list of priority diseases, or

Stakeholders that have a responsibility to provide and improve diagnostic services in the country, for example, those involved in general health system improvement, technical partners, professional organizations of health workers, or government stakeholders who may have not had much input to date.
These different groups of stakeholders require a different approach:
For the first group of stakeholders the

For the second group of stakeholders the

content.value: The outcome of

Phase 3 will use the outcomes of Phases 2A and 2B to inform the development of the draft
. The
will consist of four categories of diagnostic tests:
General
s that are used for anatomical and clinical pathology, clinical microbiology, clinical chemistry, hematology, pregnancy testing, etc.
Disease-specific
s that are used in the diagnosis, treatment monitoring, screening, or surveillance of specific communicable or non-communicable diseases.
Blood-screening
s that are used for the detection by blood screening laboratories and blood banks of transfusion-transmitted organisms.
Imaging technologies

items.name: Phase 2B
items.subTitle: Situational analysis of the health system and laboratory system and network

content.value: development should take existing structures into account in order to make use of them and (at a later stage) reinforce them. To identify the current state of the structures that are needed for implementation of the
, a situational analysis of the health system as well as the laboratory system and network must be performed at an early stage of the
development process.
is aimed at making a list of diagnostic tests already implemented in the country. In
these tests will be labelled as candidate
to be scrutinized for inclusion in the
is aimed at making an overview of imaging technologies already implemented in the country. This will also serve as basis for including (additional) imaging technologies into the

is aimed at obtaining insight in the laboratory network and system. A laboratory network is divided into different tiers parallel to the health system. Specimen referral mechanisms ensure transportation of specimens from health facilities, sample collection points, or laboratories at lower tiers to laboratories at higher tiers of the network for (reference) testing. Results are subsequently communicated from the reference laboratory to the referral laboratory or health facility. This creates a network in which laboratory services, from simple to most advanced, can be offered to the entire population in all parts of the country.

For continuous provision of quality laboratory services, laboratories, and the laboratory network, need to be supported by a laboratory system. A laboratory system consists of different components that can be classified into:
Organizational components: ensuring adequate regulation, organization and management of laboratory services.
Resource components: ensuring provision of adequate funding, infrastructure, equipment, human resources, consumables, and reagents.
Support components: ensuring quality, safety, security, and proper data management.

The relation between the laboratory network and system is shown in the figure below, whereby the laboratory network, represented by the triangle, is supported by the laboratory system surrounding the laboratory network.

Understanding the structure and functioning of the laboratory network, including the specimen referral systems, and the laboratory system, provides crucial information for the allocation of diagnostic tests to the different tiers of the laboratory network, important for both the development of the
and the
implementation plan.
is focused on assessing the funding landscape for diagnostic services, providing information on the resources available for mainstreaming and improving diagnostic services through the

implementation plan to increase access to diagnostic and imaging services (
Laboratory to which specimens are referred for diagnostic testing. This is not necessarily a laboratory at the national level.
Laboratory referring specimens to a reference laboratory for reference testing.

Network of laboratories divided into different tiers parallel to the health system, where specimen referral mechanisms ensure transportation of specimens from health facilities, sample collection points, or laboratories at lower tiers to laboratories at higher tiers of the network for (reference) testing and where results are communicated from reference laboratories to the referral laboratories or health facilities. Additional activities, such as (re-)distribution of reagents and consumables, may also be possible within the laboratory network.
A system consisting of organizational, resource and support components aimed at supporting laboratories and the laboratory network for continuous provision of quality laboratory services.
Laboratory services, imaging services, and testing services at community level, providing data required for diagnostic decision making.

items.name: Activity 2B.3
items.subTitle: Laboratory network and system assessment

content.value: To create an overview of the structure and functioning of the  laboratory network, including the services offered at the various tiers and sample referral systems, and the laboratory system.

In most countries, laboratories are part of a laboratory network. A laboratory network is divided into different tiers parallel to the health system. Specimen referral mechanisms ensure transportation of specimens from health facilities, sample collection points, or laboratories at lower tiers to laboratories at higher tiers of the network for (reference) testing. Results are subsequently communicated from the reference laboratory to the referral laboratory or health facility. This creates a network in which laboratory services, from simple to most advanced, can be offered to the entire population in all parts of the country.

For continuous provision of quality laboratory services, laboratories, and the laboratory network, need to be supported by a laboratory system. A laboratory system consists of different components that can be classified into:
Organizational components: ensuring adequate regulation, organization and management of laboratory services.
Resource components: ensuring provision of adequate funding, infrastructure, equipment, human resources, consumables, and reagents.
Support components: ensuring quality, safety, security, and proper data management.

The relation between the laboratory network and system is shown in the figure below, whereby the laboratory network, represented by the triangle, is supported by the laboratory system surrounding the laboratory network.
A good understanding of the current structure and functioning of both the laboratory network and system is required for the development of the
and
implementation plan. Information from these assessments is necessary to define desired tiers for diagnostic tests when developing the

. It is also required for determining which improvements are required at the various tiers in order to implement diagnostic tests at desired tiers and to implement target diagnostics. In this activity both the laboratory system and the laboratory network are assessed. The latter includes mapping of laboratory facilities and specimen referral systems as this information is essential for the correct allocation of diagnostic tests to the various tiers in the
in

items.name: Activity 2B.4
items.subTitle: Assess the funding landscape for diagnostic services

content.value: To obtain insight in the funding landscape of diagnostic services in the country and identify factors that may facilitate or hamper the implementation of the
Although the financing of laboratory services was already reviewed at a higher level during the previous activity (Step

), it is important to obtain a more detailed insight in the funding landscape and mechanisms for diagnostic services including imaging services. This will provide important information for development of the
and, in particular, the
implementation plan.

items.title: Assess the funding landscape for diagnostic services

content.value: It is important that during this assessment the financing of both direct costs and indirect costs of all (aspects of) diagnostic services are investigated. This includes the extent to which indirect costs are covered and the identification of funding gaps. The assessment must look specifically at financing of consumables, commodities and human resources for all diagnostic services.
The assessment must provide insight in the current budgets available for (aspects of) diagnostic services and actual expenditures through annual accounts data.
Budget analysis must include:
Analysis of funding of diagnostic services by the government.
Analysis of funding of diagnostic services by development partners.
Investigation of insurance coverage of diagnostic services.
Analysis of out-of-pocket expenses required for diagnostic services.
Analysis of other funding sources.
Analysis of the situation with regard to sustainable domestic sources, including free diagnostics initiatives.

items.title: Investigate budget sufficiency

content.value: Discussions with the

â€™s Directorate of Laboratory Services as well laboratory managers from the different tiers of the laboratory network and representatives of diagnostic imaging services must be conducted to gain insight into the (perceived) status of the budget, including questions on:
Sufficiency of the budget for diagnostic services.
Sufficiency of reimbursements in the case of national health insurance coverage.
In case of shortage of budget: what are the root causes of the funding gaps?
Availability of the budget (including lag time for ordering of goods and services).
If applicable, are revenues generated by the diagnostic services reinvested in these diagnostic services?

items.title: Critically assess findings

items.name: Phase 2A
items.subTitle: Situational analysis of disease prevalence

content.value: The primary function of the National Essential Diagnostics List (
) is to improve patient care by optimizing access to diagnostic and imaging services to ensure optimal patient management. As prevalence of a disease is the best indicator of the
number
of people profiting from improved access to diagnostic and/or imaging services, the development of the

must be driven by country-specific disease prevalence data. However, these data are often scarcely available and obtaining a representative overview of which diseases and conditions are most prevalent may be challenging. Burden of disease can be used as a proxy parameter, but some rare diseases may be overrated as they may cause a substantial burden of disease due to high morbidity and/or mortality despite a low prevalence. The approach employed in this tool is intended to gain insight into (sub)national disease prevalence.

The approach must focus on infectious and non-infectious diseases and on conditions that do not fall under â€œdiseasesâ€ (for example accidents or pregnancy-related health care) or are not specific to one disease (for example antibiotic resistance). It is crucial to concentrate on those diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management.

The outcome of Phase 2A is a prioritized list of high-prevalence diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management. This list will inform the development of the draft
in Phase 3. Phase 2A consists of:
a structured desk review of scientific literature, grey literature, and existing international databases (
a disease prevalence assessment of in-country databases (
a survey among medical doctors working in routine patient care at different tiers of the health system (
In the last activity of Phase 2A (
) findings from all activities will be consolidated by the
through a consensus approach into one prioritized list of diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management.
Referring to certain part(s) of the country, for example one or more provinces.
Referring to an area covering multiple countries, including the country for which the
is being developed, for example South-East Asia.

items.name: Activity 2A.1
items.subTitle: Estimate disease prevalence by desk review

content.value: Obtain country-specific disease prevalence data from different literature and data sources to guide the identification of the most prevalent diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management. This will be used for the development of the

The desk review entails analyzing information on the prevalence of diseases and conditions in the country, focusing on diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management. This desk review concentrates on three different types of sources:
Scientific literature.
Grey literature in the form of reports, university theses, etc.
Publications and platforms on the national, regional, and global burden of disease (
As the aim of the desk review is to collect information on the
current
prevalence of diseases and conditions in the country, it is not necessary to perform an exhaustive review of historical data. The desk review must be limited to the last 10-15 years.

Some diseases may have a variable sub-national prevalence. E.g.: malaria may be prevalent in lower parts of a country and rare in mountainous parts. If indications are found that certain diseases have a high prevalence only in certain parts of the country, this must be noted.

items.title: Divide the tasks to be performed
items.responsible: Chairperson of the literature review expert group

content.value: During an initial meeting, the literature review expert group makes a list of (potential) sources of information. This list can be divided into sources related to scientific literature (Step
), grey literature (reports, theses, etc.) (Step
), and
information (Step

The tasks of identifying and scrutinizing these information sources can be divided among the members of the literature expert group, for example by the formation of teams concentrating on one type of information source.

items.title: Collect and analyze scientific literature

content.value: PubMed (nih.gov)

is the main source for scientific publications that can be used for identification of disease prevalence data. In addition, do not hesitate to use Google for identification of additional data sources relevant for the country (e.g. search for â€˜prevalence + country nameâ€™).
Scientific literature tends to be biased towards infectious diseases, in particular Human Immunodeficiency Virus (
), malaria and tuberculosis (
) and to rare or new diseases with a high morbidity and/or mortality and/or epidemic potential, such as Ebola or COVID-19. This needs to be taken into consideration when analyzing the information.
A useful technique may be â€œsnowballingâ€: the identification of new information sources from the references of sources that are identified during Steps
and

items.title: Identify and analyze grey literature in the form of reports from the country or the region

content.value: Grey literature can be a valuable source of information on disease prevalence, especially on prevalence of country specific diseases and conditions.
Possible sources of grey literature:
Ministry of Health reports
National health survey reports
Reports of the National Public Health Laboratory and national reference laboratories
Vertical program reports (e.g.
, malaria, non-communicable diseases
, antimicrobial resistance
, maternal health care, etc.)
Reports of departments responsible for collating and analyzing health data
Reports produced by technical partners, non-governmental organizations (
) and donors (e.g. annual program reports)
Publications from national and regional initiatives (e.g. Africa Centers for Disease Control)
BSc, MSc and PhD theses written by students
This list may be expanded based on the health data landscape in the country.
Like in Step
, these reports may be biased towards infectious diseases, in particular
, malaria and

and other vertical programs, and rare or new diseases with a high morbidity and/or mortality and/or epidemic potential, such as Ebola or COVID-19. This needs to be considered when analyzing the information.
The aim of the desk review is to collect information on the
current
prevalence of diseases and conditions in the country, thus try to identify the most recent complete report for each disease or condition.
A useful technique is â€œsnowballingâ€: the identification of new information sources from the references of sources that are identified during Steps
and

items.title: Identify and analyze publications and platforms on the GBD

content.value: Note that the approach of this tool is to collect data on prevalence of disease, not burden of disease. However, in the absence of (reliable) prevalence data, burden of disease data can be used as a proxy parameter.
The following formal sources on national burden of disease can be used:
Institute for Health Metrix and Evaluation (
Global Burden of Disease Study 2019 (GBD 2019) Data Resources | GHDx (healthdata.org)
Provides data from the Global Burden of Disease Study.
Country Profiles | Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (healthdata.org)
This platform is maintained by the
of the University of Washington, U.S. and contains
country profiles.
Countries | World Health Organization (who.int)
The
maintains country overviews which can be used to obtain insight in disease burden at country level.
Global Health Observatory (who.int)
The Global Health Observatory, also maintained by the
, can be used to obtain insight in disease burden at country level.
Burden of Disease - Our World in Data
Global Cancer Observatory (iarc.fr)
The Global Cancer Observatory (

) is an interactive web-based platform presenting global cancer statistics to inform cancer control and cancer research. The platform focuses on the visualization of cancer indicators using data from the International Agency for Research on Cancer (
)â€™s cancer surveillance.
The aim of the desk review is to collect information on the
current
prevalence of diseases and conditions in the country, so it is important to analyze the most recent complete set of country data from each source.

items.title: Present consolidated findings from the desk reviews in a report to the NEDC

content.value: During a plenary session of the literature review expert group, all findings from Steps
and

. must be consolidated into one report indicating the diseases and conditions with the highest (estimated) prevalence in (parts of) the country and that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management. This must include both communicable and non-communicable diseases as well as conditions that are not a disease (for example maternal health care or accidents). Where burden of disease data is used as a proxy parameter in the absence of disease prevalence data of acceptable quality and relevance, this has to be clearly indicated.
The report must include the following elements:
The methodology followed

A list of the top 25 (or more if country resources permit) most prevalent diseases (including both communicable and non-communicable diseases) and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management. This list is ideally be based on the prevalence data of the disease in (parts of) the country, but in the absence of disease prevalence data of acceptable quality and relevance, burden of disease data can be used as a proxy parameter. This must be clearly indicated in the critical analysis.
A critical analysis describing the limitations encountered (for example emphasis on
and malaria, data absence or scarcity for certain diseases, reliability of information, etc.)
A list of documents and websites that were identified and analyzed.
This report must be submitted to the

items.name: Activity 2A.2
items.subTitle: Conduct disease prevalence assessments

content.value: Identify and analyze disease prevalence data based on available databases
As described in the introduction to
, the primary function of the
is to improve patient care by optimizing access to diagnostic and imaging services to ensure optimal patient management. As prevalence of a disease is the best indicator of the
number
of people profiting from improved access to diagnostic and/or imaging services, the development of the
must be driven by country-specific disease prevalence data.
Prevalence data of diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management are ideally consolidated in national (electronic) databases.

items.title: Make an inventory of available national and sub-national databases

content.value: During an initial meeting, the disease prevalence assessment expert group makes a list of (potential) databases that may provide information to determine the disease prevalence for a variety of diseases and conditions in the country.
Examples of sources are:
District Health Information System 2 (
), a widely used health information management system
Laboratory/health/disease Information Management System(s) in the country
Public Health facility electronic health record aggregate statistics

Depending on the number and size of the identified sources, and the quality of data stored therein, the disease prevalence assessment expert group may decide to divide into teams that each concentrate on the collection and analysis of data from part of these sources.

items.title: Collect and analyze data

content.value: Each identified information source needs to be scrutinized and data needs to be analyzed to determine the prevalence of diseases and conditions relative to each other.
The analysis must for each data source also include a critical assessment of:
Diseases and conditions that are and are not included in the database
Over- or underrepresentation of diseases in the database (for example due to presence or absence of diagnostic capacity for specific diseases)
Inclusion of data from all tiers of the health system in the database
Data quality (presence of critical parameters to estimate disease prevalence)
The analysis has to concentrate on diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management.

Note that the prevalence of certain diseases and conditions observed at the lower tier(s) of the health system may drastically differ from the prevalence observed at the higher tiers (for example uncomplicated diabetes) but may be responsible for a substantial actual prevalence in the country.
In addition, as also explained in the short description of

: some diseases may have a variable sub-national prevalence. E.g.: malaria may be prevalent in lower parts of a country and rare in higher parts. If indications are found that certain diseases have a high prevalence only in certain parts of the country, this must also be noted.

items.title: Present findings in a report

content.value: During a plenary session of the disease prevalence assessment expert group, all findings must be consolidated into one report. The report must include the following elements:
The methodology followed
A list of the top 25 (or more if country resources permit) most prevalent diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management.
A critical analysis describing the limitations encountered (Step
A list of the databases that were identified and analyzed.
This report must be submitted to the

items.name: Activity 2A.3
items.subTitle: Conduct a survey to determine the perspective of medical doctors on priority diseases and conditions

content.value: To establish a prioritized list of diseases and conditions for which diagnostic and/or imaging services are required for optimal patient management as perceived by medical doctors at various tiers of the health system.
In
and
, prevalence data have been extracted from literature and databases. However, these may be incomplete or biased. Medical doctors (
) working in routine patient care are another important source of information for identifying the most prevalent diseases and conditions in the country.

Information on perceived prevalence will be determined through a survey among medical doctors. As different disease patterns are seen at different tiers of the health system and may differ between different parts of the country, it is important to include medical doctors working at all tiers of the health system and in all regions in the country. Their combined experience, collected through the survey, informs the creation of a list of prioritized diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management.

items.title: Select medical doctors to be included in the survey

content.value: Using purposive sampling, the disease prevalence assessment expert group selects cohorts of medical doctors that are responsible for patient care at different tiers of the health system, in different parts of the country and (at tiers where this is applicable) representing different specializations. Each cohort must be representative for factors such as age, gender, and seniority within the cohort (e.g., if 90% of the medical doctors at community level are aged under 30, this cohort must include 90% of informants under 30). The selection must focus on doctors working in routine patient care rather than academic staff, public health staff, etc.
The exact size of the sample will depend on the size of the country and must be determined by the disease prevalence assessment expert group, in particular the epidemiologists.
The expert group (or the
support staff) must also collect the correct contact details for each participant.

items.title: Amend the template survey and write introductory letter

content.value: The
Template Survey
must be amended to the national situation and may include the findings of
and

Subsequently, the format in which the survey will be distributed must also be decided. This can be paper-based, as an electronic file, as a survey using a survey tool (for example MS Forms), or as an app. The format with the highest potential response rate should be chosen.
The Executive Secretary of the expert group must prepare an introductory letter signed by the Chairperson of the
that clearly describes the purpose of the

, the process of its development, and the role the medical doctors selected as respondents of the survey will play. It is important to include a clear deadline for answering the survey (suggestion: 2 weeks).
If ethical clearance is required for conducting the survey, this process must be started well in advance to ensure that there are no delays.

items.title: Send the survey and monitor responses

content.value: After selection of the respondents and the preparation of the survey and the introductory letter, the
support staff must distribute the survey among the participants and collect the answers.
After the deadline has passed, participants who have not yet answered the survey must receive a reminder with a revised deadline (suggestion: 1-2 weeks).

If participants have not responded after this second deadline, they must receive a third and final deadline (suggestion: 1 week). If appropriate, personal follow-up in the form of an email or call can be included as well.

items.title: Analysis and consolidation of the survey responses

content.value: The raw data generated by the survey must be consolidated.

The outcome of this Step must represent the views of the respondents on prevalence at the various tiers of the health system and in different parts of the country. This must lead to one consolidated list of most prevalent diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management.

A critical analysis of the findings can be performed by the expert group members, but it must be clear which are the opinions of the respondents, and which are those of the members of the expert group.

items.title: Presentation of the survey findings in a report

content.value: The outcome of Step
must be presented in a report to inform the

discussions when preparing the list of priority diseases and conditions that require diagnostic and/or imaging services for optimal patient management. This list will be used for the preparation of the NEDL (
The report must include the following:
Introduction, including the objective of the survey.
The methodology followed, including survey topics, protocol and organization, and an overview of the sampling strategy, and participant names and affiliations.
One consolidated list of diseases and conditions based on the survey outcomes generated in Step
Points for consideration resulting from the survey outcome. These can be considerations that are important when designing the draft
The raw data generated during the survey may be added as an annex or supplement to this report. This may need to be anonymized.
The report must be submitted to the

Before final selection, potential conflicts of interest must be assessed for each aspirant member.
There is no defined group size for the expert groups. The size and composition of each expert group has to guarantee that its activities can be completed accurately and efficiently.
Possible profiles of members of the various groups are listed below:
Expert group
Suggested profile of members
Literature review expert group

Epidemiologists capable of extracting and analyzing disease prevalence data from literature. This group must include methodologist(s) with expertise in finding and assessing (for its quality and strength) publications.
Disease prevalence assessment expert group
Epidemiologists capable of extracting and analyzing diseases prevalence data from databases such as health management information systems, laboratory information systems, etc.
Health system expert group
Medical doctors, including pathologists, health system experts and supply chain experts capable of assessing the diagnostic system including the provision and use of diagnostic tests.
Laboratory services expert group

Laboratory experts capable of conducting and analyzing laboratory network and system assessments. These include but are not limited to: medical laboratory specialists (covering microbiology, hematology, molecular biology, clinical chemistry and anatomic pathology) and supply chain experts.
Imaging expert group
Imaging experts capable of assessing the use of the various imaging techniques at different tiers of the health system.
Health finance expert group
Health economists and financing experts capable of assessing the funding landscape for diagnostic services.

If any member feels that they cannot commit the required amount of time and/or effort, they have to indicate this at this moment to be replaced with another person with similar expertise.

items.title: Prepare a SMART operational plan for the development of the NEDL

content.value: This
operational plan has to cover Phases 2-4 of this tool.
Elements to be included:
All activities and steps of Phases 2-4 of this tool.
Regular meetings (at least quarterly) between the chairperson of the
and the
(and other relevant stakeholders as required) to provide progress updates and keep them involved and committed.
The preparation and distribution of regular progress reports to maintain an adequate paper trail of the
development process. These progress reports may also be required by the
and partners, among others for financing purposes.
The
Template SMART operational plan
can be used for making the
operational plan.
Ensure that the operational plan is
, which means that all activities are specific, supplemented with an indicator of completion, agreed with the
and expert group members, and have a deadline with a realistic allocation of time and resources for completion.
The
operational plan must be finalized during a plenary meeting of the
and all expert groups to ensure the involvement and commitment of all members.

In addition, a system of regular progress reporting by the Executive Secretary of the

items.title: Quarterly updating of the SMART operational plan

content.value: Monitoring:
As planning concerns the future and unexpected events may occur, the progress of implementation of the
operational plan needs to be monitored. This is the responsibility of the Chairperson of the
but can be delegated to another member of the
(for the
activities) or the Chairpersons of the expert groups (for expert-group-specific activities).
Updating
: Based on the monitoring information, time frames and responsible persons may need to be amended. This must be done by the
chairperson in close consultation with the persons involved.
